msgSnippet: ... [from a four year old memory ...] If you are using a resource that needs to be closed (ie. implements Closeable), you put it in a /using/ block :
messageBody:
On 7/27/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>
> > Something like C#'s /using/ keyword to close Closeables would not suck.
>
> Could you please elaborate. I am only dipping my toes into c# so I'm
> not familiar with all aspects of the language.
>

[from a four year old memory ...]

If you are using a resource that needs to be closed (ie. implements
Closeable), you put it in a /using/ block :

using(resource) {
resource.useIt();
}

and the resource will be closed when you are done with it.

Presmably, you can also do

using(resource = new Resource()) {
resource.useIt();
}


It's syntactic sugar for Java's

try {
resource = new Resource();
resource.useIt();
}
finally {
try {
if(resource != null) {
resource.close();
}
}
catch(Exception e){}
}

Kevin
